Message 2294 of 4024
I would prefer we not have the “document-off’s”. It’s not productive for our children and the email history will bear out the truth. Let’s please stop.
We left a child therapist meeting together. Our cars were parked next to each other. No one followed anyone, but document what you wish.
We also committed to discussing how we could talk about our children in real time at the actual event that they were at in their best interest on Friday
.
You made a very explicit request for me to sit next to you . I asked we text instead. But you were very clear you would prefer to do it with me in
person.
Let’s stop trying to rewrite what has happened. It’s in our OFW history. Let’s please just be kind for the kids and our mental health. I wish you the
best!
Sent:03/24/2024 at 09:55 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/24/2024 at 10:02 AM)
Subject:Re: Post Therapy Discussion
Message 2295 of 4024
You came over and sat next to me.
You presented me with two options and said those were the ONLY two - Text or live discussion.
I communicated I was uncomfortable with either and said OFW.
You insisted and said I had to pick from those two. I said if I had to pick, sit next to me, but I did not want that and wanted OFW.
I communicated I would think about it, and I feel pressured EVERYTIME.
To confirm - OFW.
Sent:03/24/2024 at 10:05 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 03/24/2024 at 10:05 AM)
Subject:Re: Post Therapy Discussion

Message 2296 of 4024
I wish you the best. I do not want to pressure you. I’m just looking for ways that we can effectively coparent. Why don’t we table this whole
discussion. I don’t want to rile up any more passionate feelings. We trigger each other and we know that. Let’s just hope each other has a wonderful
day and we can be kind for the sake of our children next time we cross paths..
Sent:03/24/2024 at 10:07 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/24/2024 at 10:10 AM)

Message 2297 of 4024
Yes.
- "ICS" had an Auction.
- SAAS had "SAAS in the City"
I had asked you if we could go to the SAAS event but did not hear back. I am not blaming you by any means, but we should have attended, given we,
as a family, probably have more to be thankful for than almost anyone in attendance. We need 3rd party email.
As such, we desperately need an updated and accurate RO filed if we want to effectively co-parent in the best interest of our children. Nothing we did
at SAAS, Dr Brown, AAU, Keri Betts, and finding Adrian in Kirkland, etc.. could have happened without email.
I realize I hear every weekend it will be fixed "this week," but it never is. So, without getting mad or upset at each other, can you just blame me for your
attorney filing the wrong one? Or you changing your mind repeatedly on what it says and just get it fixed?
None of this should be controversial. I agree you two can both blame me for your actions.
thanks!

Subject:Re: Communication as Healthy Coparents

Message 2310 of 4024
Yeah, I get it. It's the same thing every week. It's just insulting to live Groundhog Day over and over. I have used the Charlie Brown & Lucy analogy so
many times that it's gotten tired and worn out. So, let me begin by highlighting once again my intention to engage in a cooperative process focused on
our children's best interests, Max and Adrian. Those two boys and their mental health are my singular concern at this point.
Seven months after I sent you my initial parenting plan, following the instructions of our co-parenting counselor (who you were secretly triangulated
with), we have yet to make progress. This is despite the involvement of five professionals and the creation of six plans consistent with our strategy to
prioritize our children's well-being in a minimally invasive process to establish a our temporary parenting plan.
However, after Dr. Brown's contributions were dismissed due to her purported lack of information and professional qualifications, coupled with the
reflections that involving her was a mistake, indicated a broader and more profound issue. You have a pattern of dismissing professional advice to stall
progress and allow yourself more runway to alienate Max and Adrian further. Thereby creating a false reaffirmation of your self-fulfilling prophecy.
We are months and months into this pattern. It's so well documented that saying otherwise is not worth the airtime. But in Baseball Terms, the
scoreboard reads:
Parenting Plans
- Robert: Six
- Christine: Nil
Excuses for no Parenting Plan
- Robert: Nil
- Christine: ♾
This underscores our imbalance in effort and the missed opportunities to collaboratively establish a plan centered around Max and Adrian's well-
being.
Following our discussion with Ms. Betts and her confirmed unwillingness to contribute to a parenting plan or offer recommendations. A critical gap
emerged in our joint commitment to the well-being of Max and Adrian. A commitment based on the guidance of qualified, child-centered therapists
driven by five therapists, six parenting plans, and the overdue addition of children's voices advocates.
Your approach suggests an unwillingness to cooperate with professionals if their recommendations don't align perfectly with a preconceived legal
strategy to take the kids, a stance made very clear with Debbie Bayer in November. This prioritization of tactics over Max and Adrina's well-being
undermines our collective decision-making process and, most importantly, their best interests.
Your new strategy, however, seems to be taking the voice of parentally alienated, possibly mentally abused children (Max and Adrian) as your primary
input and ignoring the real and lasting damage of your unilateral policies over the last nine months. This feels akin to blindfolding Max and Adrian,
playing my voice while they endure a metaphorical lashing, and using their cries against me to justify your approach.
Relying on this after-the-fact downstream data to support yourself and Google searches that align with your point of view to craft a temporary
parenting plan is inconsistent with our agreed-upon approach. If your new legal strategy replaces Dr. Brown's comprehensive work (3.5 months, 900
meeting minutes, two parenting plans, tens of guidance and recommendations emails), I urge you to reconsider your approach.
Seeing Max on Saturday, his transformation was so profound that I barely recognized him. The experience was incredibly painful. Adrian's shift from
being my "mini-me" to almost no contact dramatically underscores the impact of your parenting decisions. Removing all family photographs and
digital memory frames, which chronicled years of our life together, makes sense. It is your "digital book burning" to erase our shared moments of joy,
to achieve the same abhorrent intent as its traditional counterpart.
Sent:03/25/2024 at 11:43 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/25/2024 at 12:05 PM)
Subject:Re: Communication as Healthy Coparents

I thought this would be a quick reply, but after typing this far, I realize that the gravity of our situation requires a more comprehensive appeal. Your
current trajectory, prioritizing legal strategy over our children's mental and emotional well-being, is deeply concerning. I hope you will consider the
more profound ramifications of our ongoing conflict to Max and Adrian.
Given we are only moving backward, and the children have no father figure, only an evolving villain, I propose we recommit to setting aside our
differences and engaging in meaningful, constructive dialogue. This is in the interest of Max and Adrian's health, happiness, and stability. As Dr.
Brown keeps telling us, let's look forward instead of hurting the kids with personal retribution-based parenting decisions, a pattern I humbly suggest
we unfortunately share.
Are you open to discussing next steps and how we prioritize the well-being of Max and Adrian?
-robert

versa. So, feel free to just ask me directly. There is no need to pay Annalisa to request something I've been trying to give you for over a month. As

Thanks again for your work on this, Christine.

... to see the salutation and sign-off of the Annalisa emails to Lisa in a different font. I assume it's intentional to show me that she did not really have
anything to do with the content but add those two elements, increase the degrees of separation in the telephone game by two, bill additional money to
both of us via separate attorneys, and have it reach me, asking me to resend something I sent three times... lol
Come on, just send me the request next time. I don't ever push back. Hell,, I even initiated this info exchange without you even asking. I know the
drill, babe. Then when you said nothing, I sent it again anyway. And even after you acknowledged you got it a month ago, you then asked via
AnnaLisa again. She already works for you. It's not like you need to make some sort of case for her because I won't provide it to you.
This is becoming a bad divorce parody. It's like she has a spell on you and you don't think for yourself anymore. Then, when you do, it just gets
reversed with an explanation that you had just not had a chance to talk to her yet. I am here for you and the kids!  And if you can't work with me on
something like this, how on earth do we expect to work on a custody plan? Please start trying, Christine. I'm all in, as I promised today.

Message 2324 of 4024
I hate you are asking me to wait to talk to our Lawyers when we have been told as recently as yesterday that our child is considering self-harm. And it
is documented in this thread that we are quite possibly the primary contributing factors since your actions of July 4th and 5th.
I can't bear the idea of watching an undersized casket lowered into the ground and wishing that our attorneys were not your only go-between for
something that could have saved ADs life. It's so bizarre we could have lost him 36 hours ago, yet today, you roll the dice on purpose.
I'll contact my attorney to understand what you are doing or saying to our children, noting Ms. Betts seemed very concerned to learn how our
situation has never been explained to them. I can't believe you're making me badger you to collaborate on keeping Adrian from killing himself.
Yes, I will definitely speak to my attorney about this. And as a refresher on what I asked for in September, please see below for my proposal you
ignored. And to make things worse, made everything noted as "not to do" your guiding strategy. Which I never understood.
I just reread ... I can't help but think if we had picked my route instead of yours, as you insisted, Adrian would not be thinking of killing himself. Just
think how different our kid's lives would be right now. Blame it on January to feel better, but you ignored this for months prior to that.
All I want is for Max and Adrian to have a safe place for themselves. You have created the opposite. Your parenting decisions are incredibly
disturbing, and I fear they will have lifelong, or as we have been warned now possible life-ending consequences. Sound safe?
Sent:03/26/2024 at 08:42 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/26/2024 at 09:27 AM)
Subject:Re: Our Room

______________________ From my Parenting Plan sent to Christine in Sept.______________________
Talking with Max and AD: It’s evident that Max and AD sense that changes are occurring. It’s pivotal that we discuss this matter with them with
utmost care, empathy, and clarity. A conversation where we convey a unified and reassuring message is essential, emphasizing that their well-being is
our top priority.
- Love and Reassurance- They must know our love for both is steadfast. It's vital to reassure them that we will both persistently be a significant part of
their lives. The essence is that no one is being excluded, and no one is "voted off the island."
- Avoiding Blame- We must maintain neutrality in our conversation and refrain from attributing blame to the instigator of this process. It’s crucial to
present the decision as mutual to mitigate distress, irrespective of the underlying dynamics.
- Maintaining Consistency- Ensuring some sense of normality in our separation is crucial for their mental well-being now and in the future. We need
to underscore the consistent elements, like schooling and activities, to foster a sense of stability.
- Encouraging Feedback- Allowing Max and AD to express their thoughts, fears, and uncertainties is essential. Validating their emotions and ensuring
that such feelings are normal, and we are here to support them will be necessary.
- Honesty and Clarity- While it’s unnecessary to delve into the intricate details of our separation, they have witnessed our fights. So, being honest
about the impending changes is essential, and providing the timelines we know will be helpful.
- Living Arrangements- While we have not finalized long-term living arrangements, we should have a near-term plan if the previously defined
arrangements are satisfactory. Clarifying interim plans and assuring them of our continual presence is critical.
- Addressing Concerns- Max and AD might initially be reticent but encouraging them to ask questions and providing honest and reassuring responses
is vital. It’s acceptable to acknowledge uncertainties while demonstrating a united front for them.
Co-Parenting Guidelines: We must portray a united, loving front for Max, AD, and Elsa to ensure they feel they originate from love, not discord,
especially as we navigate through our differences. A collaborative approach will establish a secure environment and reinforce their sense of being
cherished.
- Avoiding Conflict- We must refrain from disagreements in the kid's presence to shield them from unnecessary stress and emotional turmoil. Our
children are not instruments in our disputes; maintaining a peaceful environment is paramount.
- Positive Role Modeling- Demonstrating mutual respect and effective, peaceful communication is crucial. We are tasked with exhibiting behaviors
that promote their social and emotional growth. They will look to us to learn how to behave.
- Prioritizing Their Needs- Ensuring the well-being of our children surpasses any disagreements or conflicts we have is essential. Our commitment to
their needs must be visible and unwavering, transcending our differences.
- Consistent Messaging- Presenting a united front and avoiding contradictory information will provide stability and prevent potential anxieties and
trust issues. Consistency in communication is vital in fostering a secure environment for them.
- Family Time- Regular, supportive dialogue during this will ease smoother transitions and adjustments to new family dynamics and living situations.
The basics provided in the family planning section above should be helpful to this effort.
- Unified Discipline Approach- Supporting consistency in discipline will fortify trust, ensuring our children perceive our unified values and
preventing potential manipulative scenarios. Neither of us should be perceived as the "heavy" or the "softie."
- Family Planning: For the mental well-being of our children during our ongoing separation, we acknowledge the importance of maintaining safe and
respectful shared family time. Christine and I agree that our interactions during these times will be peaceful, especially in the presence of the children.
Any discourse must be private.

Scheduled Family Dinners- Regularly scheduled family dinners should be arranged to foster stability and create trust for the children's benefit. We
will mutually agree upon the dates, ideally incorporating one weekday and one weekend.
- Event Attendance- Whenever appropriate, we aim to jointly attend events and appointments to show united support for our children, reinforcing
our shared priorities. This will demonstrate that their needs are the number one priority in our lives.
- Shared Responsibilities- We will collaboratively manage responsibilities, such as attending appointments and school events, alternately or as agreed
upon. Due to the chaotic nature of events, ad-hoc arrangements continue to be acceptable.
- Flexibility and Cooperation- We will strive to accommodate unforeseen circumstances and each other’s schedules to maintain a harmonious co-
parenting environment and foster a sense of teamwork. I will accommodate Christine's work conflicts.
- Communication and Advance Notice- Transparent and timely communication is essential. Any information or updates about upcoming events or
appointments should be shared promptly to allow time for schedule adjustments if desired.
- Respect for Boundaries and Time- Mutual respect for time and commitments is crucial. If one parent cannot attend an event, the attending parent
should share relevant information and updates about the proceedings with the other.
- Neutral Debriefings- Post-event debriefings should be conducted impartially and factually to ensure parents are informed and aligned on
subsequent co-parenting decisions. Let's agree on the format as that is 1-1.
